danfulea.math.numerical

Class LinAEq

  • java.lang.Object
    • danfulea.math.numerical.LinAEq

  • public class LinAEq
extends java.lang.Object
    Linear Algebric Equations class
    Based on Numerical Recipes in C (Cambridge Univ.).
    Author:
    Dan Fulea, 26 SEP. 2006.

    • Method Detail

      • gaussj

        public static void gaussj(double[][] a,
                          int n,
                          double[][] b,
                          int m)
        Linear equation solution by Gauss-Jordan elimination. a[1..n][1..n] is the input matrix. b[1..n][1..m] is input containing the m right-hand side vectors. On output, a is replaced by its matrix inverse, and b is replaced by the corresponding set of solution vectors. AX=B it is solved simultaneously m linear equation systems. If m=1 we have one system of equations.
        Parameters:
        a - a
        n - n
        b - b
        m - m

      • gauss

        public static double gauss(double[][] a,
                           int n,
                           double[][] b,
                           int m)
        Gaussian elimination with backsubstitution. The input data are the same as in gaussj.
        Parameters:
        a - a
        n - n
        b - b
        m - m
        Returns:
        the determinant of a.

      • ludcmp

        public static void ludcmp(double[][] a,
                          int n,
                          int[] indx)
        Given a matrix a[1..n][1..n], this routine replaces it by the LU decomposition of a rowwise permutation of itself [LU=A]. a and n are input. a is output, arranged as : ß11 ß12 ß13 ß14;a21 ß22 ß23 ß24;a31 a32 ß33 ß34;a41 a42 a43 ß44. indx[1..n] is an output vector that records the row permutation effected by the partial pivoting; d is output as ±1 depending on whether the number of row interchanges was even or odd, respectively. This routine is used in combination with lubksb to solve linear equations or invert a matrix.
        Parameters:
        a - a
        n - n
        indx - indx

      • lubksb

        public static void lubksb(double[][] a,
                          int n,
                          int[] indx,
                          double[] b)
        Solves the set of n linear equations A·X = B. Here a[1..n][1..n] is input, not as the matrix A but rather as its LU decomposition, determined by the routine ludcmp. indx[1..n] is input as the permutation vector returned by ludcmp. b[1..n] is input as the right-hand side vector B, and returns with the solution vector X. a, n, and indx are not modified by this routine and can be left in place for successive calls with different right-hand sides b. This routine takes into account the possibility that b will begin with many zero elements, so it is efficient for use in matrix inversion.
        Parameters:
        a - a
        n - n
        indx - indx
        b - b

      • inverseMatrix

        public static double[][] inverseMatrix(double[][] a,
                                       int N,
                                       int[] indx)
        Using the above LU decomposition and backsubstitution routines, it is completely straightforward to find the inverse of a matrix column by column. The matrix y will now contain the inverse of the original matrix a[1..N][1..N], which will have been destroyed.
        Parameters:
        a - a
        N - N
        indx - empty indx [1..N] to be used by LU routines.
        Returns:
        the result, y the inverse matrix of a.

      • determinantMatrix

        public static double determinantMatrix(double[][] a,
                                       int N,
                                       int[] indx)
        The determinant of an LU decomposed matrix is just the product of the diagonal elements. Input data are the same as in inverseMatrix.
        Parameters:
        a - a
        N - N
        indx - indx
        Returns:
        the determinant

      • tridag

        public static void tridag(double[] a,
                          double[] b,
                          double[] c,
                          double[] r,
                          double[] u,
                          int n)
        Solves for a vector u[1..n] the tridiagonal linear set given by equation: TRImatrix x uvecor = rvector. b is the main diagonal array. TRImatrix have a2,b1,c1,...aN,bN,cN-1 tridiagonal elements (the rest are 0). a[1..n], b[1..n], c[1..n], and r[1..n] are input vectors and are not modified. Solution is stored in u.
        Parameters:
        a - a
        b - b
        c - c
        r - r
        u - u
        n - n

      • triDiag

        public static void triDiag(double[] a,
                           double[] b,
                           double[] c,
                           double[] d,
                           int n)
        Alternative approach for tridiagonal matrices. Solution is stored in d.
        Parameters:
        a - a
        b - b
        c - c
        d - d
        n - n

      • mprove

        public static void mprove(double[][] a,
                          double[][] alud,
                          int n,
                          int[] indx,
                          double[] b,
                          double[] x)
        Improves a solution vector x[1..n] of the linear set of equations AX = B. The matrix a[1..n][1..n], and the vectors b[1..n] and x[1..n] are input, as is the dimension n. Also input is alud[1..n][1..n], the LU decomposition of a as returned by ludcmp, and the vector indx[1..n] also returned by that routine. On output, only x[1..n] is modified, to an improved set of values.
        Parameters:
        a - a
        alud - alud
        n - n
        indx - indx
        b - b
        x - x

      • improveLU

        public static double[] improveLU(double[][] a,
                                 int n,
                                 int[] indx,
                                 double[] b)
        Improved LU method. The input data is the matrix a[1..n][1..n], an empty indx[1..n] vector and right-hand vector b[1..n].
        Parameters:
        a - a
        n - n
        indx - indx
        b - b
        Returns:
        the improved set of values.

      • svbksb

        public static void svbksb(double[][] u,
                          double[] w,
                          double[][] v,
                          int m,
                          int n,
                          double[] b,
                          double[] x)
        Solves A·X = B for a vector X, where A is specified by the arrays u[1..m][1..n], w[1..n], v[1..n][1..n] as returned by svdcmp. m and n are the dimensions of a, and will be equal for square matrices. b[1..m] is the input right-hand side. x[1..n] is the output solution vector. No input quantities are destroyed, so the routine may be called sequentially with different bs.
        Parameters:
        u - u
        w - w
        v - v
        m - m
        n - n
        b - b
        x - x

      • svdcmp

        public static void svdcmp(double[][] a,
                          int m,
                          int n,
                          double[] w,
                          double[][] v)
        Given a matrix a[1..m][1..n], this routine computes its singular value decomposition, A = U·W·V Transpus. The matrix U replaces a on output. The diagonal matrix of singular values W is output as a vector w[1..n]. The matrix V (not the transpose V T ) is output as v[1..n][1..n].
        Parameters:
        a - a
        m - m
        n - n
        w - w
        v - v

      • pythag

        public static double pythag(double a,
                            double b)
        Computes (a^2 + b^2)^1/2 without destructive underflow or overflow.
        Parameters:
        a - a
        b - b
        Returns:
        the result

      • svd

        public static void svd(double[][] a,
                       int N,
                       double[] b,
                       double[] x)
        A more convenient use of SVD method. Solves AX=B.
        Parameters:
        a - input matrix a [1..N][1..N]
        N - N
        b - input right-hand vector b[1,,N]
        x - the solution vector X.

      • vander

        public static void vander(double[] x,
                          double[] w,
                          double[] q,
                          int n)
        Solves the Vandermonde linear system sum from i=1 to N xi^(k-1)wi = qk (k = 1,...,N). Input consists of the vectors x[1..n] and q[1..n]; the vector w[1..n] is output.
        Parameters:
        x - x
        w - w
        q - q
        n - n

      • toeplz

        public static void toeplz(double[] r,
                          double[] x,
                          double[] y,
                          int n)
        Solves the Toeplitz system sum j=1 to N of R(N+i-j)xj = yi (i = 1, . . . ,N). The Toeplitz matrix need not be symmetric. y[1..n] and r[1..2*n-1] are input arrays; x[1..n] is the output array.
        Parameters:
        r - r
        x - x
        y - y
        n - n

      • choldc

        public static void choldc(double[][] a,
                          int n,
                          double[] p)
        Given a positive-definite symmetric matrix a[1..n][1..n], this routine constructs its Cholesky decomposition, A = L · LT . On input, only the upper triangle of a need be given; it is not modified. The Cholesky factor L is returned in the lower triangle of a, except for its diagonal elements which are returned in p[1..n].
        Parameters:
        a - a
        n - n
        p - p

      • cholsl

        public static void cholsl(double[][] a,
                          int n,
                          double[] p,
                          double[] b,
                          double[] x)
        Solves the set of n linear equations A · x = b, where a is a positive-definite symmetric matrix. a[1..n][1..n] and p[1..n] are input as the output of the routine choldc. Only the lower subdiagonal portion of a is accessed. b[1..n] is input as the right-hand side vector. The solution vector is returned in x[1..n]. a, n, and p are not modified and can be left in place for successive calls with different right-hand sides b. b is not modified unless you identify b and x in the calling sequence, which is allowed.
        Parameters:
        a - a
        n - n
        p - p
        b - b
        x - x

      • qrdcmp

        public static void qrdcmp(double[][] a,
                          int n,
                          double[] c,
                          double[] d)
        Constructs the QR decomposition of a[1..n][1..n]. The upper triangular matrix R is returned in the upper triangle of a, except for the diagonal elements of R which are returned in d[1..n]. The orthogonal matrix Q is represented as a product of n- 1 Householder matrices Q1 . . .Qn-1, where Qj = 1-uj x uj/cj. The ith component of uj is zero for i = 1, . . . , j -1 while the nonzero components are returned in a[i][j] for i = j, . . . , n. sing returns as true (1) if singularity is encountered during the decomposition, but the decomposition is still completed in this case; otherwise it returns false (0).
        Parameters:
        a - a
        n - n
        c - c
        d - d

      • qrsolv

        public static void qrsolv(double[][] a,
                          int n,
                          double[] c,
                          double[] d,
                          double[] b)
        Solves the set of n linear equations A · x = b. a[1..n][1..n], c[1..n], and d[1..n] are input as the output of the routine qrdcmp and are not modified. b[1..n] is input as the right-hand side vector, and is overwritten with the solution vector on output.
        Parameters:
        a - a
        n - n
        c - c
        d - d
        b - b

      • rsolv

        public static void rsolv(double[][] a,
                         int n,
                         double[] d,
                         double[] b)
        Solves the set of n linear equations R · x = b, where R is an upper triangular matrix stored in a and d. a[1..n][1..n] and d[1..n] are input as the output of the routine qrdcmp and are not modified. b[1..n] is input as the right-hand side vector, and is overwritten with the solution vector on output.
        Parameters:
        a - a
        n - n
        d - d
        b - b

      • rotate

        public static void rotate(double[][] r,
                          double[][] qt,
                          int n,
                          int i,
                          double a,
                          double b)
        Given matrices r[1..n][1..n] and qt[1..n][1..n], carry out a Jacobi rotation on rows i and i + 1 of each matrix. a and b are the parameters of the rotation: cos theta = a/sqrt(a2 + b2), sin theta = b/sqrt(a2 + b2).
        Parameters:
        r - r
        qt - qt
        n - n
        i - i
        a - a
        b - b

      • qrupdt

        public static void qrupdt(double[][] r,
                          double[][] qt,
                          int n,
                          double[] u,
                          double[] v)
        Given the QR decomposition of some n × n matrix, calculates the QR decomposition of the matrix Q·(R+u x v). The quantities are dimensioned as r[1..n][1..n], qt[1..n][1..n], u[1..n], and v[1..n]. Note that QT is input and returned in qt.
        Parameters:
        r - r
        qt - qt
        n - n
        u - u
        v - v

      • sysEqGauss

        public static double sysEqGauss(double[][] a,
                                double[][] b,
                                int n,
                                int m)
        Gaussian elimination with backsubstitution. The input data are the same as in gaussj. This is gauss above...with different name. Must be a left-over.
        Parameters:
        a - a
        n - n
        b - b
        m - m
        Returns:
        the determinant of a.

      • sysEqTriDiag

        public static void sysEqTriDiag(double[] a,
                                double[] b,
                                double[] c,
                                double[] d,
                                int n)
        Alternative approach for tridiagonal matrices. Solution is stored in d. This is the same as triDiag....must be some left-over.
        Parameters:
        a - a
        b - b
        c - c
        d - d
        n - n
